newsitem.title: HUNGARY: SWISS MAY FACE 5-YEAR JAIL FOR CD-PIRACY IN HUNGARY.
newsitem.headline: SWISS MAY FACE 5-YEAR JAIL FOR CD-PIRACY IN HUNGARY.

text.p: A Swiss citizen caught in Hungary with pirated software worth almost two billion forints ($13 million) could face a five-year sentence if found guilty, police said on Thursday.

"We just received expert opinion putting the value of the software at around two billion forints," Lieutenant-Colonel Zoltan Marton, head of the crime prevention unit of Szekesfehervar (central Hungary) police, told Reuters.

He added that the 30-year-old man, only identified as David J. G., has been found carrying 2,500 CD-ROMs with pirated software in his car during a routine police road check in August and was taken into custody.

The suspect also had on him a receipt for $5,000, the amount he paid a Hungarian company for copying the software, but according to Hungarian police the company was unaware of the illicit nature of the operation.
Marton said versions of Microsoft 's Windows operating system and Borland 's developer software were found among the pirated programs.
Copyright violation is the only software-related crime in Hungary as there is no customs duty on software, unlike for hardware.

Earlier this week, industry sources said the computer hardware black market accounts for up to a quarter of Hungary's information technology turnover of 100 billion forints ($645 million) a year, while as much as ninety percent of memory modules could come from illegal imports.
